questions.text: A female patient is admitted following a domestic assault during which she sustained an isolated head injury. On admission she had a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 13/15 but remained confused. She was therefore admitted overnight for observations. You are called to see her by the high-dependency unit nurses who have noticed a drop in her Glasgow Coma Scale score to 8/15. On examination you note her left pupil is now fixed and dilated. The most likely cause of this is
Jackson’s zone of burn injury is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the order or description of the zones of injury is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: A zone of hyperemia inside a zone of stasis

options.label: B
options.text: A zone of hyperemia superficial to a zone of stasis, with a deeper zone of coagulation beneath

options.label: C
options.text: A zone of coagulation at the surface of a burn wound, a zone of stasis within the injured dermal layer, and a deep zone of hyperemia characterized by vasodilated subcutaneous vessels

options.label: D
options.text: A zone of coagulation, surrounded by a zone of stasis, which is surrounded by a zone of hyperemia

questions.correct_answer: D. A zone of coagulation, surrounded by a zone of stasis, which is surrounded by a zone of hyperemia

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain and mild elevations in lipase (3 x ULN) diagnostic of acute pancreatitis. The patient describes multiple episodes of pain and associated pancreas enzyme elevations since early childhood that generally respond to brief hospitalizations and conservative treatment including intravenous fluids and IV analgesics. CT imaging reveals parenchymal calcifications seen throughout the pancreas. Further history discloses two relatives with similar pain attacks. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely to be associated with the cause of the recurrent pancreatitis in this patient?

A 21-year-old female underwent ERCP for choledocholithiasis. Biliary cannulation was difficult and a needle-knife sphincterotomy was performed. Stones were removed and occlusion cholangiogram did not reveal any filling defects. The next morning, the patient presents with severe epigastric abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. Her lipase is 4000 IU/L (normal 0-60 IU/L). What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat ERCP with pancreatic duct stent placement

questions.text: A 54-year-old alcoholic male with a history of recurrent acute pancreatitis undergoes a CT scan for abdominal pain that reveals pancreatic parenchymal calcifications and a dilated main pancreatic duct of 11 mm. There is no evidence of a pancreatic mass or evidence of duodenal obstructive symptoms. What is the best long term management of pain in this patient with chronic pancreatitis?

A 64-year-old male with a recent history of acute pancreatitis has a dilated main pancreatic duct with prominent side branch lesions seen on CT scan. Endoscopic evaluation reveals mucus extruding from a dilated ampulla. What is the next best step in management of this patient?

You are asked to see a 45-year-old female patient on the ward. She is approximately 30 minutes following the insertion of a left internal jugular vein catheter sited for total parenteral nutrition. A plain film chest radiograph has not yet been performed following the procedure. The nursing staff is concerned as the patient is breathless. On arrival, the patient's air- way is patent, but she is breathless at rest. Her respiratory rate is 30 breaths/ min. The trachea is central. Her pulse is 110 beats/min and blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. There are reduced breath sounds on the left and the left chest is hyper-resonant to percussion. Select the most appropriate diagnosis and management strategy.

options.label: A
options.text: Tension pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy 5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line

options.label: B
options.text: Simple pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy 5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Chylothorax; immediate insertion of large-bore cannula, 2nd inter- costal space, mid-clavicular line

questions.correct_answer: B. Simple pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy 5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is blue-lighted into the emergency department following an accident at work. A pan of hot cooking oil had spilled over half of his back and over both his legs and he has sustained extensive burns in this distribution. He weighs 70 kg. Calculate the volume of crystalloid this patient will require in the first 8 hours (from the time of his burn) of his treatment using the ATLS formula and the Wallace Rule of Nines.

A 53-year-old female with remote history of necrotizing pancreatitis presents with massive UGI bleeding requiring intravenous fluids and blood transfusions. After stabilization in the emergency department and transfer to the ICU, EGD reveals large gastric varices with a red wale sign, without esophageal varices. Which of the following is the definitive management for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Interventional radiology consultation for visceral angiogram and embolization

questions.text: A 57-year-old female presents with intermittent abdominal pain, heart burn and nausea. The patient also reports diarrhea, up to three to four loose bowel movements per day. An upper endoscopy reveals esophagitis, antral erythema with erosions and multiple small ulcerations in the duodenum. Small bowel biopsies show inflammation with mild villous atrophy. Celiac sprue serology and gastric biopsies are unremarkable. The above clinical symptoms are most consistent with which of the following neuroendocrine tumors?

A 31-year-old female with history of alcohol abuse presented at an outside hospital two months ago with acute pancreatitis. Her hospital course was complicated by necrotizing pancreatitis and questionable pancreatic duct leak. She now presents to see you for persistent abdominal pain, early satiety and nausea, vomiting. Labs reveal WBC 9,000 cells/mm3, AST 52 U/L, ALT 30 U/L, alk phos 90 U/L, TB 1.5 mg/dl You get a repeat CT with contrast as below. What is collection noted on the CT?

24-year-old female undergoes CT for abdominal pain and nausea. CT, as below, revealed a 3.5 cm pancreatic tail cystic lesion with peripheral calcification, though further evaluation is recommended with MRI. She denies any history of pancreatitis or family history of pancreatic cancer. She denies any weight loss. MRI as below revealed the 3.5 cms hyperintense lobulated lesion with peripheral calcifications and possibly debris or solid component within. Labs reveal a normal CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel. Amylase and lipase are normal. CA 19-9 is 6 U/mL (normal 0-35 U/mL). EUS is performed for further evaluation and it reveals a solid hypoechoic mass with some calcifications without any obvious cystic areas.

A 65-year-old female with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department after a fall. CT abdomen reveals a pancreatic neck three cm grape cluster-like cystic mass with a central scar. She is asymptomatic and has no abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss or family history of pancreatic cancer. MRI is performed, that reveals a microcystic mass as below without any solid component. CBD and PD are normal in caliber. EUS is performed and fluid CEA is less than 5 ng/mL.What is the most likely diagnosis?
An initial primary survey of the chest is intended to quickly identify the follow- ing causes of cardiorespiratory compromise, except

A 48-year-old man is admitted with a burn over his arm and anterior chest. The involved tissue includes the entire circumference of his upper arm. Following initial resuscitation, he is admitted for observation. You are called to assess him as he is beginning to complain of increasing pain and tightness in his forearm. On examination you note weak peripheral pulses, paraesthesia and pain on active movement of the fingers, hand and wrist. The next stage in management is

A 75-year-old male with no significant past medical history presents with dyspepsia and 15 kgs unintentional weight loss. Labs reveal a normal CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel (including hepatic function panel). EGD shows mild chronic inactive gastritis without any ulcers or concerning lesions. CT abdomen as below reveals a three cm pancreatic body mass that is encasing the celiac artery bifurcation. No metastasis is noted on CT. CA 19-9 is 500 U/mL (normal 0-35 U/mL) . Endoscopic ultrasound is performed and FNA of the mass reveals pancreatic adenocarcinoma. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

A 45-year-old female is admitted with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, associated with nausea and vomiting. On admission her pulse is 90 beats per minute and BP 110/70 mm Hg. On physical exam she has significant epigastric tenderness with mild guarding, but no rebound tenderness. Labs reveal lipase greater than 10,000 U/L, AST 350 U/L, ALT 450 U/L, TB 6.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 400 U/L, WBC 20,000 cells/mm3. Ultrasound showed multiple gallstones in the gallbladder, with dilated common bile duct measuring 1.5 cm in diameter. She is started on aggressive IV fluids with lactated ringers and broad spectrum antibiotics. Three hours after admission she develops fever with temperature of 101.5 degrees F with HR of 100/min and BP 90/60 mm Hg. What is the next best step?

A 45-year-old female was recently admitted with gallstone pancreatitis and was hospitalized for one week. She is now five weeks out from her admission and is tolerating a low fat diet well. Today at her follow up appointment she denies any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. CT performed two days ago revealed a nine cm pancreatic fluid collection suggestive of a pseudocyst, as seen below. Her WBC is 6,000 cells/mm3 and hepatic function panel is within normal limits. Her amylase and lipase are within normal limits. She denies any early satiety or fever.

options.label: D
options.text: Expectant management with repeat imaging in six weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. Expectant management with repeat imaging in six weeks

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to your clinic for further nausea, vomiting and jaundice. On exam, her abdomen is soft, non-tender and not distended. Her sclera are anicteric. Laboratory studies are obtained and reveal a total bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 24 IU/L, AST 18 IU/L, ALT 19 IU/L. Her MRCP image is shown here. For definitive management, you recommend:

A 40-year-old depressed and schizophrenic man jumps off a three-story window onto the street. Paramedics arrive on scene within 5 min, and he is rushed to the emergency department but loses vitals in the field and is dead on arrival (DOA). What is the most likely cause of death?

Following a motor vehicle crash (MVC), a 35-year-old male is found to have a significant right-sided renal hilar injury on imaging. He becomes hemodynamically unstable, despite intravenous fluid resuscitation and massive transfusion protocol. The decision is made to take him to the OR. What incision should you use?

A 35-year-old woman who underwent cholecystectomy three days previously presents to the ED for further evaluation of RUQ abdominal pain and fevers. On physical exam her abdomen is tender in the RUQ with guarding and rebound. Labs reveal a total bilirubin of 2 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 150 IU/L, AST 60 IU/L, ALT 82 IU/L, lipase 50 U/L (50 ULN), WBC 16.4 10^9/L. Cross sectional imaging is performed and reveals this finding seen here. The next best step in management is:

A 40-year-old woman presents to your clinic for further evaluation of RUQ abdominal pain. The patient reports intermittent RUQ pain which occurs every two to three months. It typically will last 30 minutes to one hour and resolve. In between episode she feels well. It is not improved with acid suppression or bowel movements. She underwent cholecystectomy for cholecystitis 10 years prior. LFTs have been obtained during these episodes. Labs following her most recent episode reveal a total bilirubin of 1 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 50 IU/L, AST 103 IU/L, ALT 110 IU/L, and lipase of 10 U (ULN 50 U). A prior episode six months ago revealed a similar elevation in her AST and ALT. MRCP was performed and revealed a CBD which measured five millimeters without evidence of a filling defect. EUS is performed and is unrevealing. You recommend:

A 36-year-old man with recurrent RUQ pain associated with meals is seeing you in clinic. Aminotransferase levels have been measured with these episodes and have been normal. He underwent a RUQ US which did not reveal cholelithiasis; however, an 11-mm non-mobile echogenic lesion was noted within the gallbladder wall. You recommend:

options.label: B
options.text: A repeat US in one year

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to your office for further management of right upper quadrant pain over the last one year. The patient reports intermittent episodes of severe 9/10 RUQ pain every two to three weeks. The pain typically lasts one to two hours and resolves spontaneously. She has no improvement with defecation. On exam her abdomen is soft not tender or distended. Labs obtained during one of her pain episodes show an AST of 14 IU/L, ALT 24 IU/L, Bili 0.8 mg/dL, ALP 92 IU/L, and lipase of 32 U. She has undergone RUQ ultrasound without stones or sludge. There is no pericholecystic fluid or wall thickening. Endoscopic ultrasound was performed, and a four millimeter CBD was visualized with no microlithiasis within the CBD or gallbladder. The ampulla was normal in appearance as well as the remainder of her upper GI tract. CCK- stimulated cholescintigraphy is obtained and demonstrates a GBEF of 22 percent. This patient most likely has:
Which of the following sets of clinical signs are usually associated with a basal skull fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: Periorbital ecchymoses, CSF otorrhoea, retroauricular ecchymoses, cranial nerve III palsy

options.label: B
options.text: Periorbital ecchymoses, CSF rhinorrhoea, anosmia, cranial nerve VI palsy

options.label: C
options.text: Rib fracture, CSF otorrhoea, CSF rhinorrhoea, anosmia

options.label: D
options.text: Periorbital ecchymoses, CSF otorrhoea, CSF rhinorrhoea, retroauricular ecchymoses

questions.correct_answer: D. Periorbital ecchymoses, CSF otorrhoea, CSF rhinorrhoea, retroauricular ecchymoses

questions.text: Which of the following patients do not meet the criteria for referral to a burn center?

options.label: A
options.text: A 50-year-old woman with a 1% TBSA partial-thickness burn on her left hand from a cooking accident

options.label: B
options.text: A 30-year-old construction worker with pain and blistering bilaterally on the knees after kneeling in wet cement all afternoon

options.label: C
options.text: A 25-year-old man with 7% TBSA partial-thickness burns on the chest

options.label: D
options.text: A 42-year-old woman with no cutaneous injury, found lying down at the scene of a house fire, and noted

questions.correct_answer: C. A 25-year-old man with 7% TBSA partial-thickness burns on the chest

questions.text: An 89-year-old woman presents with black stools as well as RUQ pain radiating to her shoulder as well as nausea and vomiting. She denies any prior episodes of abdominal pain. On exam, her abdomen is distended and tender to palpation. Labs are notable for a WBC of 18.2, Hgb 10 gm/dl, previously 12, ALT 147 IU/L, AST 376 IU/L, T bilirubin 2.8 mg/dl. CT imaging reveals a markedly dilated stomach without small bowel dilation. The gallbladder is heterogenous in appearance with several calcified stones. The GB wall is thickened and appears inseparable from the adjacent duodenum. Air is seen within the gallbladder lumen. The CBD is not dilated. She has no prior history of biliary instrumentation. The next best step in management of this condition is:

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical consultation with consideration of therapeutic upper endoscopy

questions.correct_answer: A. Surgical consultation with consideration of therapeutic upper endoscopy

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to your clinic for further evaluation of abdominal pain. On exam, the patient’s abdomen is soft, not tender and not distended. You note icteric sclerae. Labs are obtained and demonstrate an AST of 92 IU/L, ALT 87 IU/L, Bili 3 mg/dL, ALP 180 IU/L, and lipase is 23 U/L. A RUQ ultrasound demonstrates ductal dilation but no cholelithiasis or sludge. MRCP is subsequently performed and is shown here. ERCP is performed with the image shown .The most common clinical presentation of this condition is:

A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, recurrent fevers, and worsening jaundice. He has a past medical history significant for recurrent episodes of cholangitis, ascites, and esophageal varices. A CT scan (below) is performed in the emergency room. MRCP performed several weeks earlier is shown below: Which of the following is true regarding this patient’s diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is the most common renal manifestation.

options.label: B
options.text: Cyst aspiration and sclerotherapy are indicated.

options.label: C
options.text: This patient is at increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: This patient’s liver disease is secondary to parasitic infection.

questions.correct_answer: C. This patient is at increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the office after Roux-en-Y surgery for weight loss. She has a strong family history of gallstones, and asks about measures to prevent gallstone formation after her surgery. Which of the following agents has potential efficacy to reduce gallstone formation for this patient?

A 70-year-old woman with hepatitis B cirrhosis was admitted after a witnessed episode of hematemesis. She is currently in the intensive care unit and is intubated and sedated. Vitals include T 98.0o F, BP of 104/62 mmHg, HR 88 beats per minute. Abdomen is soft without ascites. Labs include AST 60 U/L, ALT 40 U/L, total bilirubin of 2.1 mg/dL, albumin of 3.2 g/dL, Hemoglobin of eight g/dL, INR 1.2, and a platelet count of 75,000/µL. She is started on antibiotics and an octreotide infusion. You perform an upper endoscopy and there is fresh clot in stomach and large esophageal varices with red wale signs. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic Band ligation and start nadolol

questions.correct_answer: B. Endoscopic Band ligation and start nadolol

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a stab wound to the chest. He is combative and with severe shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 94/76 mmHg with a pulse of 120/min and respiratory rate of 28/min. Physical exam reveals a 2 cm stab wound on the left chest. Lung fields on the left have decreased breath sounds and are hyperresonant to percussion. His neck veins are distended. A needle is placed in the left second intercostal midclavicular line and aspirated until a gush of air is heard escaping the chest wall. A liter of normal saline is given, and blood pressure improves to 120/70 mmHg, and pulse decreases to 100/min. What is the best next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Transport to the operating room for exploratory thoracotomy

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient has been in the burn intensive care unit(ICU) intubated and sedated for 2 weeks after an 80% TBSA burn. He suddenly develops hypotension, tachycardia, and melena. What type of surgical problem is this patient mostlikely to have?

A 56-year-old man with recently diagnosed hepatitis B is in your office for further evaluation for new diagnosis of liver cancer. He has no other past medical history and is a former smoker. He recently started tenofovir. His exam is notable for palpable hepatomegaly without evidence of jaundice, spider angiomata, or palmar erythema. His current blood work includes AST 120 U/L, ALT 150 U/L, sodium of 137 mEq/L, total bilirubin of 1.8 mg/dL, albumin of 3.7 g/dL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL, INR of 1.0 and a platelet count of 150,000/µL. You review his most recent MRI, which reveals a three centimeter segment 3 lesion and a two centimeter segment 7 lesion. Both lesions demonstrate arterial enhancement and venous washout. There is no evidence of vascular invasion or extrahepatic disease. What is the next best step in management?

A 29-year-old male was accidentally struck on the side of his head by a cricket bat. On arrival at the Emergency Department he was unconscious, with bruising over the region of his right temporal region and an ipsilateral dilated pupil. CT scan demonstrated a fracture of the region marked in the picture below. Which of the following arteries is most likely to have been damaged?
Which of the following is correct regarding the skin substitutes used in burn reconstruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Cultured epidermal autografts have dramatically increased survival in patients with nearly 100% TBSA burn injuries.

options.label: B
options.text: Allografting to burn wound sites is limited to temporary closure because of eventual rejection of the graft by the patient.

options.label: C
options.text: Porcine xenograft has the advantage of better early vascularization and engrafting after placement as a result of decreased antigenicity in comparison to most cadaveric human allografts.

questions.correct_answer: B. Allografting to burn wound sites is limited to temporary closure because of eventual rejection of the graft by the patient.

questions.text: Regarding the surgical management of vascular injuries in the neck, all of the following are correct except:

options.label: A
options.text: The external jugular vein can be ligated if the internal jugulars are intact.

options.label: B
options.text: The internal jugular vein may be ligated unilaterally.

options.label: C
options.text: The external carotid artery can be safely ligated.

options.label: D
options.text: Unilateral ligation of the internal carotid may be safely performed.

questions.correct_answer: D. Unilateral ligation of the internal carotid may be safely performed.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with NASH cirrhosis is in the office for a follow up. His albumin is 2.9 g/dl, ALT is 89 U/mL. A contrasted CT of the liver shows arterial enhancement of a three centimeter lesion with continuous heterogenous filling in later phases. On ultrasound it appears hyperechoic. The most likely diagnosis is

A 70-year-old man is referred for evaluation of fatigue, weight loss, and elevated LFTs. An MRI of the liver shows a three cm suspected cavernous hemangioma in the liver, multiple small nodules in the spleen, and trace ascites, but no evidence of cirrhosis. He does not drink alcohol and tested negative for viral hepatitis. He is concerned, because his younger brother died from a bleeding liver tumor, and they worked at the same factory where they were exposed to “lots of chemicals”. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: He should be referred for liver transplantation

options.label: B
options.text: Given absence of cirrhosis, he should be offered reassurance and repeat imaging in one year to ensure stability

options.label: C
options.text: His liver lesion is likely related to occupational exposure to vinyl chloride

options.label: D
options.text: His risk of intraperitoneal bleeding is low

questions.correct_answer: C. His liver lesion is likely related to occupational exposure to vinyl chloride

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma?

A 33-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with a 4-week history of rigors, weight loss, and right sided abdominal pain which radiated to his right shoulder. He had returned from a business trip to China 9 months ago. He reported two episodes of fresh rectal bleeding on return to the UK following his trip. On examination, he had a temperature of 39°C, blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, heart rate of 90 beats/minute, and hepatomegaly. Investigations: Hg -140 g/dL (130–180) TLC- 22 x 109/L (4.0–11.0) PT- 14 seconds CT abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with altered level of consciousness following direct trauma to the head by a heavy object about 3 hours prior to arrival. He was brought in by his friend, who said that he had transient loss of consciousness for about one minute after which he woke up complaining of headache and blurry vision.He vomited once before becoming somnolent and again about 30 minutes later. On general examination, his vital signs were ,BP= 140/85mmHg,RR= 18cycle/min,Pulse= 68 beat/min, and GCS = 10/15. Bruises were seen over the right temple. On neurological examination, the patient had a left hemiparesis with round, equal, and reactive pupils. T e patient was mildly agitated with good localization of painful stimuli. Regarding the diagnosis of cranial EDH,whichof the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: CT scan of the head is the standard imaging modality that reveals cranial EDH without the need for IV contrast.

options.label: B
options.text: EDH is usually crescentic in shape on CT imaging, while a SDH is more lenticular with biconvex borders.

options.label: C
options.text: The fresh, undiluted blood on an EDH appears as a hypodense mass on head CT scan.

options.label: D
options.text: A positive swirl sign on a CT scan of the head indicates a long-standing EDH, which can be treated conservatively.

questions.correct_answer: A. CT scan of the head is the standard imaging modality that reveals cranial EDH without the need for IV contrast.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident is brought to the surgery emergency with shortness of breath. HRCT was done. A 3-D reconstruction of the ct is shown. True about this condition are all except:

options.label: C
options.text: For a diagnosis fracture of >2 ribs at > 2 locations

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a part of the Revised Trauma Score?
The incision shown in the picture is?
All of the following are correct except:

options.label: A
options.text: The caudate lobe receives portal structures from both the right and left main branches.

options.label: B
options.text: The caudate process of the caudate lobe extends to and may make contact with segment 7 thus surrounding the inferior vena cava.

options.label: C
options.text: The caudate lobe is hypotrophic in Budd–Chiari syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: The caudate lobe drains directly into the vena cava.

questions.correct_answer: C. The caudate lobe is hypotrophic in Budd–Chiari syndrome.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is admitted following a stab injury to the right groin. He is bleeding profusely from the wound. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and his pulse is 140 beats/min. He is agitated and mildly confused. His skin is cool and mottled. In this scenario, which is the best mode of fluid delivery?

options.label: C
options.text: Right internal jugular approach central line

options.label: D
options.text: Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubital fossae

questions.correct_answer: D. Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubital fossae

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman was a pedestrian hit by a car while crossing the road. She complains of chest and abdominal pains. On examination, her GCS score is 14/15 (E4, V4, M6). Her vital observations are as follows: BP 86/32 mmHg; pulse 145/min. She has bruising and tenderness over her lower left 9th and 10th ribs. She has rebound tenderness and guarding over the left upper quadrant of her abdomen. Her chest X-ray demonstrates left rib fractures affecting ribs 8–10.

A 44-year-old man is involved in a road traffic accident. He was a driver of a delivery truck, travelling at 50 miles/h and was hit from the side. On arrival at A&E he is unstable. His vital observations are as follows: BP 90/32 mmHg; pulse 160/min; respirator rate 45 breaths/min. On examination, his neck veins are engorged and distended. His trachea is central with quiet heart sounds.
